simulated_ratings.title: Se7en (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Grim, propulsive, and morally gnarly in exactly my sweet spot.

simulated_ratings.title: Zodiac (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Meticulous obsession done right, hypnotic even without tidy closure.

simulated_ratings.title: Heat (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Grand, patient cops-and-robbers with characters I actually cared about.

simulated_ratings.title: The Departed (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Tense, twisty, and mean in a way I savor.

simulated_ratings.title: Prisoners (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Unflinching and suffocating, with moral rot that lingers.

simulated_ratings.title: Sicario (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bleak and gripping, though a bit emotionally remote for me.

simulated_ratings.title: No Country for Old Men (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cold-blooded and haunting

simulated_ratings.title: Memento (2000)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clever structure that actually deepens the dread.

simulated_ratings.title: Shutter Island (2010)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Moody and fun, even if the reveal felt familiar.

simulated_ratings.title: Nightcrawler (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A slick, nasty character study I couldn’t look away from.

simulated_ratings.title: The Usual Suspects (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Smartly constructed crime tale with a satisfying sting.

simulated_ratings.feeling: Vicious, operatic revenge that sticks under the skin.

simulated_ratings.title: Memories of Murder (2003)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bleak, funny, and devastating—my kind of procedural.

simulated_ratings.title: Arrival (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Thoughtful and elegant, though it kept me at arm’s length.

simulated_ratings.title: Children of Men (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gritty, urgent sci-fi that actually rattled me.

simulated_ratings.title: Minority Report (2002)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cool premise and pace, but it plays a bit glossy for my taste.

simulated_ratings.title: Blade Runner 2049 (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gorgeous and moody, more to admire than to feel for me.

simulated_ratings.title: The Thin Blue Line (1988)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Riveting and razor-precise—exactly why I love documentaries.

simulated_ratings.title: The Look of Silence (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Quietly harrowing and humane

simulated_ratings.title: Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Inventive, heartfelt, and way more stylish than I expected.

simulated_ratings.title: The Incredibles (2004)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sharp, energetic fun with just enough bite.

simulated_ratings.title: Coraline (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Creepy and imaginative, but I admired it more than I loved it.

simulated_ratings.title: Vertigo (1958)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Mesmerizing obsession with a queasy pull I appreciate.

simulated_ratings.title: North by Northwest (1959)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Breezy and polished, enjoyable if a touch lightweight for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Psycho (1960)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Still unnerving, with suspense I can’t deny.

simulated_ratings.title: Before Sunrise (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Pleasant, even charming, but a bit too wispy for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Silver Linings Playbook (2012)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Messy, sincere, and likable without totally landing for me.

simulated_ratings.title: In Bruges (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Darkly funny and surprisingly soulful—right up my alley.

simulated_ratings.title: Zero Dark Thirty (2012)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Taut and absorbing, more compelling as process than drama.

recommended_movies: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

simulated_ratings.title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cold, meticulous, and driven by two prickly leads—my kind of procedural chill.

simulated_ratings.title: Gone Girl (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A nasty, elegant marital autopsy with bite I relish.

simulated_ratings.title: Collateral (2004)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sleek, nocturnal tension with real human stakes—utterly absorbing.

simulated_ratings.title: L.A. Confidential (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sprawling, hard-edged noir with corruption that feels deliciously rotten.

simulated_ratings.title: Fargo (1996)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bleakly funny and brutal, with moral stupidity snowballing into horror.

simulated_ratings.title: Blood Simple (1984)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sweaty, mean-spirited noir—rougher edges but satisfyingly cruel.

simulated_ratings.title: The Conversation (1974)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Paranoid, methodical, and suffocating—process as character, which I love.

simulated_ratings.title: Chinatown (1974)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Elegant rot and despair that tightens like a noose.

simulated_ratings.title: Wind River (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Wintry, spare, and quietly devastating—procedural with a pulse.

simulated_ratings.title: Hell or High Water (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lean and humane crime tale with a dusty, angry thrum.

simulated_ratings.title: Michael Clayton (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Taut corporate rot with a weary soul at the center—catnip for me.

simulated_ratings.title: A Simple Plan (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Slow-burn greed and paranoia spiraling into grim inevitability.

simulated_ratings.title: The Secret in Their Eyes (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Melancholy, patient investigation where obsession scars more than it heals.

simulated_ratings.title: Mother (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Twisted, compassionate, and unnervingly single-minded—right in my wheelhouse.

simulated_ratings.title: The Chaser (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Relentless, grim, and breathless—an ugly chase I couldn’t shake.

simulated_ratings.title: The Wailing (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Oppressively eerie and ambiguous, more dread-soaked than scream-heavy in a way I dig.

simulated_ratings.title: The Vanishing (1988)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Chillingly methodical evil that crawled under my skin and stayed.

simulated_ratings.title: Manhunter (1986)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cool, clinical cat-and-mouse with style to burn, if a bit emotionally remote.

simulated_ratings.title: The Silence of the Lambs (1991)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Precise and unnerving, with character dynamics that hum with dread.

simulated_ratings.title: Thief (1981)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Hard, blue-collar crime romanticism with a fatalistic ache I appreciate.

simulated_ratings.title: Mulholland Drive (2001)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Hypnotic and unsettling—admired its pull more than I felt it.

simulated_ratings.title: The Prestige (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Obsessive, twisty rivalry where structure sharpens the dread nicely.

simulated_ratings.title: Enemy (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A murky moral spiral that makes vengeance feel queasy and inevitable.

simulated_ratings.title: A History of Violence (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Terse and bruising—identity as a lie with consequences I felt.

simulated_ratings.title: Eastern Promises (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cool-tempered brutality and grim underworld ritual that kept me hooked.

simulated_ratings.title: The Act of Killing (2012)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Transfixing, nightmarish reckoning that left me shaken to the core.

simulated_ratings.title: Waltz with Bashir (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Dreamlike excavation of memory that’s haunting and humane.

simulated_ratings.title: The Lives of Others (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Quietly devastating surveillance morality play that tightened its grip scene by scene.

simulated_ratings.title: The Insider (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Methodical, suffocating corporate rot—exactly the kind of process drama that grips me.

simulated_ratings.title: The Game (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Slick paranoia and escalation I enjoyed, even if the mechanics feel like a magician’s flourish.

simulated_ratings.title: Le Samouraï (1967)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cool, clinical fatalism that hums with dread—my kind of austere noir.

simulated_ratings.title: A Prophet (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bleak, patient rise-through-the-ranks crime story that tightened its grip scene by scene.

simulated_ratings.title: The French Connection (1971)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gritty, relentless pursuit with a nasty thrum, if a touch emotionally spare for me.

simulated_ratings.title: City of God (2002)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Kinetic, devastating crime sprawl where innocence erodes into cold-blooded reality.

simulated_ratings.title: The Long Good Friday (1980)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Ruthless and bristling, a crime boss unraveling in a way I savor.

simulated_ratings.title: The Pledge (2001)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Dogged, anti-closure obsession that left a queasy ache I appreciate.

simulated_ratings.title: Insomnia (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Guilt, daylight, and fraying sanity—moody procedural pressure I like.

simulated_ratings.title: Infernal Affairs (2002)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lean, tense dual-mole cat-and-mouse that scratched my procedural itch hard.

simulated_ratings.title: Tell No One (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Propulsive grief-tinged puzzle that kept me hooked even when it stretched plausibility.

simulated_ratings.title: The Third Man (1949)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Elegant rot and fatalism, a noir fog that settles in and chills.

simulated_ratings.title: Drive (2011)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sleek, nocturnal melancholy with bursts of brutality—cooler than it is deep for me.

simulated_ratings.title: The Yellow Sea (2010)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Relentless, grim chase with desperation baked into every beat—right up my alley.

simulated_ratings.title: Spotlight (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Methodical and humane institutional rot—process that quietly devastates.

simulated_ratings.title: Cure (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Oppressive, ambiguous evil corroding a detective’s mind—exactly my kind of dread.

simulated_ratings.title: The Imposter (2012)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Twisty, unnerving true-crime portrait where identity feels like a con game.

simulated_ratings.title: Hereditary (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Suffocating family doom and dread that lingered, even if the crescendo felt familiar.

simulated_ratings.title: It Follows (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Left me cold—flat action beats and little of the moral bite I crave.

simulated_ratings.title: The Witch (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bombastic witch-hunter fantasy that skimmed the surface for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Kill List (2011)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Starts hard, dives darker—bleak, disorienting descent that stuck under my skin.

simulated_ratings.title: Let the Right One In (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Quiet, wintry horror with bruised hearts—melancholy that worked on me.

simulated_ratings.title: Under the Skin (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Minimal, muted yearning that I respected more than I connected to.

simulated_ratings.title: The Handmaiden (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sultry, meticulous con that blooms into obsession—cold, deliciously twisty.

simulated_ratings.title: Unforgiven (1992)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A weary moral reckoning that curdles into violence—my kind of western.

simulated_ratings.title: Miller's Crossing (1990)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Ornate, hard-edged gangster chess—cool, satisfying, if a bit aloof.
